titleStmt.title: Towards Continuous Monitoring in Personalized Healthcare through Digital Twins

address.region: Ontario, Canada. ACM, NY, USA, 6 pages

analytic.title: Towards Continuous Monitoring in Personalized Healthcare through Digital Twins

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Continuous and effective monitoring of chronic diseases and their associated treatments might have a decisive impact on reducing risks and improving life quality of patients. This, however, demands new and innovative methods for engineering systems that support the required capabilities. Research on the application of the novel concept of Digital Twin (DT) in healthcare might provide the means to revolutionize traditional medical practices. A DT comprises a set of virtual representations of both the structural elements and dynamics of any physical asset (e.g., a patient) throughout its lifecycle. In the healthcare domain, it might represent a significant step forward towards tightening and improving the interactions between systems, caregivers and patients. Moreover, integrating data-driven methods (e.g., Machine Learning) and DT could serve as a noteworthy mechanism to not only track patients' health continuously, but also to evaluate the application and evolution of medical treatments virtually. In this paper, we describe our vision for the application of DT in precision medicine. Our contributions are twofold. First, we describe our initial ideas for a reference model that leverages DT capabilities and research advances in self-adaptive systems and autonomic computing to engineer smart and flexible software systems in healthcare. We expect these systems to alleviate complexity and assist in the planning and decision-making processes when applying medical treatments to patients by healthcare professionals. Then, we elaborate on the definition of internal structures for DT to support precision medicine techniques in the context of continuous monitoring and personalized data-driven medical treatments.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: The recent information explosion together with the instrumentation of artificial intelligence capabilities in modern software systems are enabling new research opportunities and innovation in the healthcare domain [16,37,41]. New emerging and interrelated paradigms such as Informatics & Data-Driven Medicine, 1 eHealth 2 and mHealth, 3 Software as a Medical Device (SaMD), 4 and Digital Health 5 are flourishing and gaining acceptance among both healthcare professionals and patients [11]. This confluence of new available medical data, sensing and data processing technologies, and the design and implementation of smart systems is expected to allow unprecedented levels of precision and personalization in healthcare and medicine. On the one hand, the successful implementation of real-time analysis through continuous monitoring of patients will improve healthcare practices that directly impact individual diagnosis accuracy including early detection of deterioration of health conditions [35], while reducing costs associated with hospital operations [39]. On the other hand, the availability and processing of large and diverse flows of health-related data are facilitating the prediction of medical treatment outcomes, even in a traditionally complex domain such as mental and psychological disorders [6,10,36]. However, achieving this introduce different challenges when engineering systems that support these capabilities [8,11,19,41].

As new data-driven personalization requirements arise, designers are facing unseen levels of complexity when defining and implementing smart healthcare systems [11]. First, large volumes of data coming from myriad and diverse devices must be integrated by these systems [24,27,38]. The explosion of data size, arising from recent devices' capacity to generate valuable information during their operation, demands new approaches for storing, processing, and managing data. Moreover, the heterogeneity of the produced data calls for adopting new practices to consolidate information in such a way that useful insights can be originated regardless of its origin. Second, the dynamism of a patient's health condition, the uncertainty associated with the variables that affect it, and the advocacy for early diagnosis and corresponding actions require effective interaction between physical and computing systems [12,18]. This implies guaranteeing an effective and accurate exchange of realtime information among different systems and devices involved in the continuous monitoring of medical states. Third, accommodating quality and safety concerns in modern healthcare demands leveraging uncertainty management, digitization, and simulation capabilities [4]. This refers to the ability to create accurate virtual abstractions of real-world entities to assist in the analysis of their current properties and the prediction of their future state.

Digital Twin (DT) is an emerging concept that offers a novel approach for virtually representing both the structural elements and dynamics of an asset throughout its entire lifecycle [31]. DT represents a significant step forward towards the achievement of integrated data, multidimensional cooperative systems, and the digitalization of both structural and behavioral characteristics of real-world entities. Although this concept manifests a promising idea that could be leveraged in different application domains such as healthcare, technological limitations have hampered its early adoption [40]. Nonetheless, recent research and advances in data collection, processing, and analysis, as well as in self-adaptive or autonomous systems, are promising to advance the realization of DT. On the one hand, Internet-of-Things (IoT) technologies along with techniques for processing large volumes of data (i.e., big data technologies) allow not only systems to gather data that was not accessible before, but also to process it regardless of its size. On the other hand, instrumenting DT-based systems with self-adaptation and intelligence supported by data mining and machine learning capabilities enables them to reason and produce new information and knowledge from historical and real-time data. Therefore, combining these techniques through DT might play a fundamental role in the proliferation of smart systems [1], which could lead to decidedly positive effects in the healthcare domain. Thus, DT technology is conducive to not only track real-time patients' health, but also to reduce the uncertainty related to the effectiveness and progression of medical treatments [7]. DT simulation capabilities might be leveraged through the simultaneous application and analysis of treatments on virtual clones. Achieving this is challenging, but recent advancements in the simulation of chronic diseases such as diabetes represent a promising opportunity for researchers, patients and medicians [3].

Despite the widely recognized significance of DT, 678 its realization is still challenging [13,25]. In fact, most of the DT-based approaches found in literature mainly feature emergent ideas and preliminary results [25], and its application is still limited, particularly in healthcare [30]. This paper posits our vision on the application of the DT concept in the continuous monitoring of patient conditions and the management of medical treatments by healthcare professionals. To realize our vision, we are working on developing a novel reference model for engineering DT-based healthcare systems based on the principles of self-adaptation and autonomic computing. Thus, the paper elaborates on the modeling 9 of smart healthcare systems' internal structures, their interrelationships, and the correspondence of associated DTs to their physical equivalents.

The remainder of this paper is structured as follows. Section 2 describes the DT concept and its main characteristics. Section 3 presents our vision for the application of DT in healthcare and a preliminary version of the proposed reference model. Section 4 discusses related work. Finally, Section 5 concludes the paper and describes directions of future work.

div.head: THE DIGITAL TWIN CONCEPT
div.p: As an emergent concept, DT lacks an accepted standard definition applicable to any domain [13,25]. This limitation, however, has not halted research efforts to provide the conceptualization required to enable future advances on this topic in different application domains. This section provides an overview of relevant DT definitions, realization requirements, and implementation challenges from both academic and industry contexts.

div.head: Definitions
div.p: Since its conception, researchers have proposed several definitions for DT [34]. Although the exact origin of the DT concept is not completely clear, its first appearance dates back to 2003 when Grieves [14] used it in the context of Product Lifecycle Management (PLM). The initial conception of DT involved a basic description of the interconnections between physical and virtual entities [40]. Since then, a plethora of revisions to the concept has enabled it to evolve and adapt according to recent trends such as IoT and Industry 4.0. The following list outlines the most important DT definitions. Digital Twin: A set of virtual representations that enables describing the fundamental characteristics of a physical entity using different levels of abstraction. A DT is a precise and up-todate virtual manifestation that continuously aggregates data 6 https://www.forbes.com/sites/bernardmarr/2017/03/06/what-is-digital-twintechnology-and-why-is-it-so-important/#6a8e8fe52e2a 7 https://www.expresscomputer.in/news/the-importance-of-digital-twins/21810/ 8 https://www.forbes.com/sites/danwoods/2018/07/18/why-digital-twins-should-bethe-ceos-best-friend/#710e64d93c75 9 We focus on the structural models of DT and their relevance for prediction and forecasting (behavioral models). However, we acknowledge (https://lfrivera.github.io/ personal-stuff/publications/lfrivera-cser2019s-poster.pdf) that additional modeling approaches must be considered.

coming from the physical counterpart [26], thus serving as a central knowledge base for both real-time analysis and forecasting. Two major uses for DT have been derived [15]: interrogation, where DTs are consulted for current and historical data, regardless of their physical counterpart location; and prediction, which involves predicting future behaviour and qualities of the physical entity, throughout its entire lifecycle, using a DT. Digital Twin Prototype (DTP): A DTP specifies the informational structures (e.g., 3D models) required to describe and generate a physical prototype from a specific virtual version. Digital Twin Instance (DTI): A DTI describes a particular physical entity linked to a DT. Privacy and security concerns might motivate the creation of multiple instances of DT for the same physical device [32].

div.head: Requirements and Challenges
div.p: Even though different DT definitions have been provided in multiple application domains, most of them share commonalities that enable analyzing DT requirements from a general perspective. Recent research [13] established that the aggregation of real-time data, integration and interoperability, and fidelity are three major requirements for the realization of DT in the context of Industry 4.0-referring to a fourth revolution in manufacturing processes, driven by recent advancements in the IT field [28]. We argue that these concepts are also highly relevant to the application of DT in healthcare.

div.head: Real-time Data Aggregation.
div.p: In a data-driven world, gathering pertinent data as soon as it is produced becomes essential to comprehend the current state of an element of interest [9]. To facilitate this, the automatic detection and binding of available physical devices in a network (e.g., wearable healthcare devices) becomes essential. Furthermore, researchers must provide new methods for adjusting the rate at which data produced in the physical domain is updated and replicated in the digital one [32]. This is crucial for the proper management of diseases that might develop critical emergency conditions in patients (e.g., diabetes). In these cases, monitoring rate or monitored properties must be adapted accordingly for adequate and early intervention.

div.head: Integration and Interoperability.
div.p: Multiple DTs might work cooperatively to achieve a shared goal [9,29,30,32,43]. To accomplish this level of interaction, DT practitioners will need to provide new suitable APIs and mechanisms that enable the automatic detection and composition of DTs available in the network to simplify the interchange and synchronization of information across organizations [32]. This would be a key factor when modeling the complex interactions that occur in the human body through the establishment of DT hierarchies depicting structural decompositions.

div.head: Fidelity.
div.p: Accurate detailing is one of the major concerns for future DT practitioners [13]. DT's fidelity refers to its capability to correspond to a physical entity precisely. This property imposes big challenges to the definition of DT's internal structures that will support detailed representations of complex physical entities such as tissues, organs, or even systems.

div.head: OUR VISION
div.p: This section provides an overview of our proposed approach towards the achievement of personalized treatments and precision health using DT for continuous monitoring and forecasting. Initially, we describe our DT-Driven reference model for the design, development, and operation of treatment management systems in precision healthcare. Then, we elaborate on the DT internal structures definition that will form the foundations of the model. Furthermore, we present a concrete application scenario where our envisioned approach could be introduced, thus detailing its use. Our model combines DT concepts with research advances in selfadaptive systems and autonomic computing such as feedback loops and autonomic managers [22], Models at Run-time (MARTs) [5], and reference models for adaptive control (i.e., IBM's Autonomic Computing Reference Architecture (ACRA) [21]). First, the model illustrates the acquisition of real-time healthcare data (context) from either a particular individual or a targeted group using noninvasive sensing equipment such as wearable devices. Continuous and diverse flows of data originated from these devices are managed by Adaptive Context Monitoring capabilities that, in the context of DT fidelity improvement, provide flexibility to sampling and data fusion processes, therefore addressing the uncertainty associated with the changing behavior of relevant context sources. In this sense, gathering data from subjects of interest is conceived as a dynamic procedure, instrumented by a context monitoring feedback loop (COM-FL), similar to the one defined in the DYNAMICO reference model [42], that enables meeting particular monitoring requirements from specific medical states or treatments, and accommodating context uncertainty originated from the development of critical health conditions. Processed data from the monitoring phase will be stored using data models governed by Adaptive Structural MARTs (cf. Figure 1) that constitute the static view of the virtual representations of the human body. These static models define the set of properties to be measured and the schemas to organize sensor readings. Furthermore, they characterize the latest known health status of the subjects under consideration. As new information becomes available or new properties are required to improve the fidelity of the virtual representations, structural models will be required to evolve accordingly. In addition, behavioral AI-based models (e.g., Online Machine Learning algorithms or Cascading Genetic Fuzzy Trees) will describe the dynamic characteristics of the entities being modeled. They enable the expected forecasting and simulation capabilities of DT technologies by exploiting the data stored in structural models and adapting according to Tuning Controllers (cf. tuning feedback loop (TUN-FL in Figure 1)) that establish policies to guarantee their correct calibration. Finally, a care management feedback loop (CAM-FL) controls the satisfaction and optimization of high-level goals for particular medical treatments. In this loop, a Treatment Management Controller performs trade-off analysis and dictates the way both run-time models and controllers must adapt conforming to individual patient demands. For instance, new symptoms or available treatment outcomes in patients with similar conditions might drive the re-definition (evolution) of both structural and behavioral modeling to meet particular needs. Creating model-based abstractions has enabled designers to tame complexity when understanding, conceptualizing, and specifying real-world entities and phenomena. This modeling process has played a fundamental role in the definition of internal structures that comprise information systems supporting daily-basis or even mission-critical tasks. However, a new arising era of complex and interconnected real-time systems, which span beyond the virtual realm (e.g., DTs), imposes new challenges to system modeling [13,45]. The proper formulation of new (meta) modeling mechanisms that enable molding DT understructures, their interrelationships, and their correspondence to physical counterparts is still a key factor towards the successful application of DT in any domain [32]. Figure 2 depicts our proposal for modeling DTs in healthcare for personalized medical treatments and precision medicine. Inspired by the divide-and-conquer paradigm, we define a Human Digital Twin (HDT) as a set of interrelated and virtual anatomical structures (AS), which might represent tissues, organs, or systems in the human body. Following the definitions of DT described in Section 2.1, we conceive the concepts of AS Digital Twin Prototype (DTP) and AS Digital Twin Instance (DTI). On the one hand, An AS DTP comprises the Adaptive Structural MARTs depicted in Figure 1, which are created and maintained by healthcare professionals and autonomic managers for describing the sensing measurements under consideration during a particular medical treatment, thus delineating a virtual representation of the real-world AS affected by the treatment. Through model transformations and synchronizations, AS DTPs manage the underlying data models that serve as an input for the AI-based model (i.e., Adaptive Behavioral MART in Figure 1). On the other hand, each AS DTI creates the conditions for simulating and evaluating the outcomes of a particular medical treatment over a specific individual or targeted group. HDT Managers (cf. Figure 1) allow the instantiation of AS DTIs from AS DTPs, thus enabling the realization of data-driven personalized medical treatments.

div.head: Motivational Scenario
div.p: Efficient and effective care of patients with chronic diseases such as diabetes calls for continuous monitoring of real-time conditions in order to prevent possible disease-related complications [23]. Moreover, the assessment of medical procedures for diabetes prevention and treatment becomes essential to improve quality of life and survival chances, determine disease progression, and reduce risks and costs associated with long-term or irremediable complications such as blindness, amputation, cardiovascular diseases, among others [44]. This section exemplifies the way our envisioned approach can be crucial in the chronic disease management of diabetes, a metabolic disorder that affects more than 400 million people worldwide, 10 and whose estimated costs have reached $327 billion in the U.S over the last years. 11 Since risks associated with diabetes are persistent, spanning long periods of time or even perpetually, diagnosed patients must learn to adhere to strict disease management in order to improve healthcare outcomes and quality of life [17]. To achieve this, continuous monitoring and analysis of relevant health signals must be guaranteed [20]. In our approach, wearable devices (e.g., smartwatches, fitness trackers, and smart clothes) provide the means for the real-time sensing and data acquisition of health-related measurements that might play an essential role in the care management of diabetes. Such measurements might include pedometer and activity-tracking data, heart rate, ingested water and food, or even glucose levels in tears and sweat. 12 . Diabetic emergencies (e.g., hyperglycemic or hypoglycemic crises) or changes in treatment goals (e.g., increasing daily physical activity) underpin the use of adaptive context monitoring in our approach. This mechanism enables both a fast response to conditions that require immediate intervention by healthcare professionals and the flexibility needed by evolving diabetes medical procedures.

Data gathered and pre-processed by monitors feed the models related to each HDT. Initially, using a DT metamodel that specifies the set of constructs to properly model DTs, healthcare professionals define an AS DTP that abstracts a desired anatomical structure in the human body. This prototype is associated with the measurements being sensed for the care management of the disease under consideration. For instance, to manage prediabetes, a medician could define an AS DTP of the endocrine system composed of Inherent Factors, such as insulin resistance; and Risk Factors, such as physical activity. However, as patients develop new medical conditions, new relevant information becomes available, or a new treatment requires changes in the set of properties being measured, the prototype should be adapted to accommodate these circumstances. For example, if prediabetes develops into type 2 diabetes, blood glucose must be considered as a new risk factor in the earlier prototype. Hence model evolution becomes essential. Data models (schemas) are generated and updated from AS DTPs in an automatic manner. Once a prototype has been defined, it can be instantiated one or multiple times as an AS DTI. Each instance encompasses a dataset corresponding to the automatically generated schema and a set of behavioral models (e.g., Machine Learning models for predicting glucose fluctuations) that provide prediction and simulation capabilities. As with their structural counterparts, behavioral models adapt accordingly.

Particular characteristics of a diabetes patient or group of interest will delineate the high-level care goals defined in the CAM-FL. This loop orchestrates control flows, thus enabling adaptive control in our approach. To exemplify this, consider, for example, the scenario of the increment of insulin resistance in a particular patient. Using the HDT Manager and historical information from the patient residing on an initial AS DTI, the Treatment Management Controller could evaluate two alternative treatments (e.g., higher medication doses and insulin injections) through two new AS DTIs, which avoids the necessity of applying them on the real subject and improves decision-making by professionals. Simulation outcomes might trigger adaption in monitoring policies, as well as in the models that compose the particular HDT under study.

div.head: RELATED WORK
div.p: Recent surveys [25,40] show that DT has received notable attention in manufacturing-related domains such as Industry 4.0. These studies, nonetheless, do not detail the application of DT in healthcare. Using both industry and academic perspectives, this section presents an overview of previous and ongoing relevant research on DT in this domain. 12 https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/01/180124113903.htm In industry, companies like Siemens, 13 Hewlett Packard Enterprise, 14 Phillips, 15 and General Electrical (GE) 16 have directly explored or contributed to the creation of accurate virtual replicas of organs such as the heart [2] or the brain [33]. These DTs perform the simulation of organs' functional units and their associated physiological processes. Moreover, companies study the use of these models in the virtual assessment and simulation of medical treatments. Furthermore, they are also investigating the adoption of DTs for modeling hospital environments with the aim to achieve improved resource planning and operations management.

As occurs with giant technological leaders, academic research recognizes the possible medical revolutions, and its implications on the life of patients, that might be driven by the DT adoption in the healthcare domain. However, only a few instances of academic publications that address the application of DT in healthcare can be found in the literature. A relevant proposal in this regard is the one described by Liu et al. in [30]. They propose a cloud-based reference framework, based on the concept of Digital Twin Healthcare (DTH), which enables real-time supervision and improved crisis warning for elderly patients. In their proposal, a DTH describes patient information, sensed properties, external factors, and patient symptoms and their optimized solution. To illustrate the feasibility of their approach, they describe its application in the context of care management of cardiac arrhythmia.

To the best of our knowledge, this is the first paper to report on the use and integration of concepts from self-adaptive systems and autonomic computing to engineer smart and flexible DT-driven healthcare systems focused on chronic disease management (e.g., diabetes). Moreover, we believe that the adoption of adaptive MARTs in our proposal, together with the division of a DT into an adaptive prototype and its particular instances, are novel applications of these concepts in healthcare.

div.head: CONCLUDING REMARKS & FUTURE WORK
div.p: This paper presented our vision for applying the DT concept in personalized medical treatments. We advocate for a modeling approach to leverage advances in autonomic and self-adaptive systems to realize such a vision. Our contributions are as follows. First, we presented preliminary work on the definition of a reference model for engineering smart healthcare systems based on DT. Our model features three feedback loops for adaptive care management, contextual monitoring and adaptive behavioral models. Second, we elaborated on DT internal structures (models) for healthcare.

Our future work will concentrate on the enrichment of our proposed reference model and its validation. For this, we will further study diabetes control treatments in order to abstract relevant modeling properties of chronic diseases and propose a healthcarerelated metamodel for DTs.

First, the model illustrates the acquisition of real-time healthcare data (context) from either a particular individual or a targeted group using noninvasive sensing equipment such as wearable devices. div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
div.p: This work was funded in part by the National Sciences and Engineering Research Council (NSERC) of Canada, IBM Canada Ltd., University of Victoria and Universidad Icesi (Colombia). The authors would like to thank IBM's Centre for Advanced Studies, Canada for supporting this project.
